channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2021 The New York Times Company

item.title: A Yearlong Cry for Help, Then Death After an Assault
item.description: Daniela Espirito Santo died after an assault by her boyfriend, who had been arrested, then released, by police. Her case is emblematic of Britain’s failure to protect victims of domestic abuse.
item.dc:creator: Jane Bradley
item.media:credit: Mary Turner for The New York Times
item.media:description: Family and friends of Daniela Espirito Santo gathered to scatter her ashes at a lake in Lincolnshire, England, last month on what would have been her 25th birthday.

item.title: As U.S. Leaves Afghanistan, History Suggests It May Struggle to Stay Out
item.description: A decade ago, a U.S. withdrawal from Iraq opened the door for the Islamic State. Will the withdrawal from Afghanistan do the same for the Taliban?
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:description: Islamic State fighters advancing through the desert in Iraq near Tikrit in 2014.

item.title: Bolsonaro Discredits Electronic Voting, Prompting Fears of a Power Grab
item.description: President Jair Bolsonaro’s attacks on Brazil’s voting system as his standing in the polls slips is drawing comparisons to the messy 2020 election in the United States.
item.dc:creator: Flávia Milhorance and Ernesto Londoño
item.media:credit: Victor Moriyama for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Jair Bolsonaro watching a parade of military vehicles at the Palácio do Planalto in Brasília on Tuesday.

item.title: Her Death Shook Japan. It May Not Shift Refugee Rules.
item.description: Wishma Rathnayake wasted away in a migrant detention center. An official report on her case placed little blame and offered only limited recommendations.
item.dc:creator: Hisako Ueno and Ben Dooley
item.media:credit: Noriko Hayashi for The New York Times
item.media:description: A photo of Wishma Rathnayake on a small altar in the house of one of her supporters, in Tsushima, Japan.

item.title: Why Most Europeans Still Can't Travel to the U.S.
item.description: America’s borders remain closed to most European travelers during the pandemic, even those fully vaccinated. With fears of the Delta variant raging, there appears to be no end in sight.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Casey
item.media:credit: Gordon Welters for The New York Times
item.media:description: Peter Fuchs, 87, at his home in Hanover, Germany. On his way to the United States in May, he was told mid-journey that he could not board his flight to New York. The experience made him feel “helpless and broken down.”

item.title: Lawsuit Against Prince Andrew Renews Questions About His Royal Role
item.description: Virginia Giuffre, one of Jeffrey Epstein’s most prominent accusers, sued the prince in New York, saying that he raped and sexually abused her when she was 17.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Mueller
item.media:credit: Jonathan Brady/PA Images, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Prince Andrew, center, in Ascot, England, in 2019.

item.title: China Upholds Death Sentence for Canadian Robert Lloyd Schellenberg
item.description: Robert Lloyd Schellenberg initially received 15 years in prison for methamphetamine trafficking. But he was handed a death sentence in a one-day retrial in 2019.
item.dc:creator: Austin Ramzy and Dan Bilefsky

item.title: Taliban Overrun Seventh and Eighth Afghan Provincial Capitals
item.description: Local officials said insurgents had flooded Pul-i-Khumri and Faizabad in the north, and Farah in western Afghanistan, making it 9 fallen cities in five days.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Najim Rahim and Taimoor Shah
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.media:description: The main bazaar in Farah city in Afghanistan’s west, in 2017.

item.title: Under Taliban Siege, 2nd-Largest Afghan City Is Struggling
item.description: For the past month, Kandahar, Afghanistan’s second-largest city, has been under siege by Taliban fighters. Families stuck between them and government forces have almost nowhere to go.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Fahim Abed and Jim Huylebroek
item.media:description: A Humvee windshield shattered by a bullet impact in Kandahar, Afghanistan.

item.title: Mexico’s President Defends News Anchor After Cartel Threat
item.description: President Andrés Manuel López Obrador came out in defense of a TV news anchor, Azucena Uresti, after she received a death threat, apparently from a powerful drug cartel.
item.dc:creator: Oscar Lopez
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: President Andrés Manuel López Obrador defended the anchor Azucena Uresti, but he is also known for his own persistent criticism of journalists.

item.title: As Wildfires Ravage Greece, Countries Send Aid
item.description: The prime minister called the fires, which have destroyed more than 200,000 acres of Greek forestland, a “natural disaster of unprecedented proportions.”
item.dc:creator: Niki Kitsantonis
item.media:description: Volunteers gathering in an open field on Sunday to support firefighters on the Greek island of Evia.

item.title: Algerian Soldiers Die Fighting Wildfires, President Says
item.description: At least 25 soldiers were killed saving residents from wildfires ravaging mountain forests and villages east of the capital, he said. The civilian death toll from the blazes rose to at least 17.
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.media:description: Smoke billowing from a wildfire on Tuesday in the forested hills of the Kabyle region, east of Algiers.

item.title: Yayoi Kusama’s Pumpkin Sculpture in Japan Is Damaged by Typhoon
item.description: A video showed violent waves thrashing the yellow pumpkin, a major tourist attraction, on the island of Naoshima.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Victor
item.media:description: The artwork, in Japan, has long been an Instagram darling, with tourists lining up to pose next to it against the backdrop of the Seto Inland Sea.

item.title: Piecing Together the History of Stasi Spying
item.description: Researchers undertake the massive task of recreating millions of torn-up records that the East German secret police hoped to destroy.
item.dc:creator: Annalisa Quinn and Mustafah Abdulaziz
item.media:credit: Mustafah Abdulaziz for The New York Times

item.title: What to Know About Breakthrough Infections and the Delta Variant
item.description: Scientific understanding of the coronavirus variant is changing quickly. Here’s a recap of the most important findings.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: Matthew Odom for The New York Times
item.media:description: Administering a Covid-19 vaccine in Moultrie, Ga., last month. The vaccines are highly effective at preventing severe illness and death, but it’s not clear how the Delta variant has affected the likelihood of breakthrough infections.

item.title: Thousands in Britain Are Trying to Save Geronimo the Alpaca From Execution
item.description: Agricultural authorities say he has bovine tuberculosis, but a local vet and a “human chain” of “alpaca angels” say the government’s test yields false positives.
item.dc:creator: Heather Murphy
item.media:description: Geronimo the alpaca at Shepherds Close Farm in Gloucestershire on Friday.

item.title: Ying-shih Yu, Renowned Scholar of Chinese Thought, Dies at 91
item.description: He believed that Chinese tradition was more varied and tolerant than critics thought it to be, and that it could be a vessel for enlightened values and democratic progress.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley
item.media:description: The scholar Ying-shih Yu in an undated photo. His beliefs were grounded in a traditional education in rural China.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing
item.description: The Taliban is advancing rapidly.
item.dc:creator: Melina Delkic
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.media:description: The main bazaar in Farah city in western Afghanistan in 2017.

item.title: Washington D.C. Public Employees to Face Vaccine or Testing Requirement
item.description: The action follows President Biden’s recent announcement that federal workers would face restrictions and requirements, including testing, if they did not get vaccinated.
item.dc:creator: Adeel Hassan
item.media:description: Public works employees and contractors are among the groups who will need to be vaccinated against the coronavirus or submit to weekly testing.

item.title: Germany to Stop Paying for Virus Tests for People Choosing to Stay Unvaccinated
item.description: People who choose not to get vaccinated will no longer get free antigen tests, starting in October.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze, Nicholas Casey, Eileen Sullivan, Davey Alba, Jason Gutierrez, Constant Méheut, Aanya Wipulasena and Saif Hasnat
item.media:description: A rapid coronavirus test center in Cologne, Germany, in June.

item.title: Saudi Arabia Lifts a Ban on Foreign Pilgrims Heading to Mecca
item.description: Starting this week, pilgrims fully vaccinated against the coronavirus by certain vaccines from outside the kingdom can apply to join the umrah pilgrimage.
item.dc:creator: Asmaa al-Omar
item.media:description: Muslim pilgrims circumambulating the Kaaba during umrah, in Mecca, in May.

item.title: Non-E.U. visitors to France can get a health pass to enter social venues.
item.description: Tourists had been concerned that they would not be allowed in cafes, museums and sporting events if their foreign vaccination certificates were not recognized.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:description: The French police checking a customer’s health pass at a Paris bar on Monday.

item.title: Virus outbreaks worsen in French overseas territories.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:credit: Cedrick Isham Calvados/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A Covid-19 patient at an intensive care unit in Pointe-a-Pitre, on the French Caribbean archipelago of Guadeloupe.

item.title: Thousands rush to vaccination sites in Manila as new virus restrictions are imposed.
item.dc:creator: Jason Gutierrez and Yan Zhuang
item.media:description: A government worker assisted people waiting to get coronavirus vaccines in Manila, Philippines on Monday.

item.title: A surge in dengue cases adds to the hospital burden in Covid-racked South Asia.
item.dc:creator: Aanya Wipulasena and Saif Hasnat
item.media:description: Patients covered with mosquito nets being treated for dengue at the Islami Bank Central Hospital in Dhaka, Bangladesh, last month.

item.title: The State of the American Mall
item.description: The pandemic has changed shopping habits. Today, we take a look at what’s happening with malls in the U.S.
item.dc:creator: Sapna Maheshwari
item.media:credit: Jesse Rieser for The New York Times
item.media:description: A former Macy’s at the now-closed Metrocenter Mall in Phoenix, Ariz.

item.title: He Worked With the U.S. for 9 Years. Now He’s Left Behind in Afghanistan.
item.description: Video calls provide a rare, intimate look into the daily life of an Afghan family whose future is hanging in the balance as the U.S. war in Afghanistan comes to an end.
item.dc:creator: Isabelle Niu
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Khyber Khan for The New York Times

item.title: The Toll of War in Gaza: Times Video Shows Survivors' Trauma
item.description: A Times video team spent weeks in the territory after the 11-day war between Israel and Hamas to document the trauma and grief of those caught in the middle.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Bahr
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: ‘We Are Here Alone’: An Afghan Translator’s Plea for Help
item.description: Starting as a teenager, Romal Noori risked his life aiding the U.S. war effort in Afghanistan. Now he’s facing a dangerous new reality as the Taliban regain power.
item.dc:creator: Isabelle Niu, Danielle Miller, Khyber Khan and Nicole Fineman
item.media:credit: Khyber Khan for The New York Times

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: Global reaction to a major climate report.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Waiting for firefighters during a wildfire next to the village of Kamatriades, Greece, on Monday.

item.title: Belarus Leader Lashes Out at the West, a Year After Crushing Protests
item.description: In an eight-hour news conference, President Aleksandr Lukashenko called Britain an “American lapdog” and took credit for averting World War III.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko and Valerie Hopkins
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Aleksandr G. Lukashenko of Belarus spoke on Monday at the presidential Palace of Independence in Minsk.

item.title: Fear Sets in as Taliban Seize Former Bastions of Resistance
item.description: The Taliban’s breakthrough victories across northern Afghanistan have sent despair rippling through the country, as many worry that no corner of the country will be spared.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum, Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Sharif Hassan and Najim Rahim
item.media:credit: Jim Huylebroek for The New York Times
item.media:description: Children who fled fighting in northern Afghanistan at a park in Kabul on Monday.

item.title: Canadian Border With United States Reopens, But Few Rush In
item.description: Carrying watercraft, bikes and hopes for a salvaged summer, some American travelers ventured north on the first day of the border reopening.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:credit: Tara Walton for The New York Times
item.media:description: Travelers crossing the International Rainbow Bridge into Niagara Falls, Ontario, from New York on Monday.

item.title: Canada Wildfires Could Intensify From a Looming Heat Wave
item.description: Wildfires are burning from Ontario to hard-hit British Columbia, where more than 1.5 million acres have been scorched since April.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai
item.media:description: Smoke envelops the small western Canadian town of Lytton after wildfires forced its residents to evacuate in June.

item.title: U.S. Signals It Will Release Some Still-Secret Files on Saudi Arabia and 9/11
item.description: The F.B.I. said it would review some long-classified documents for possible disclosure, a decision that followed a push by families of the attacks’ victims.
item.dc:creator: Katie Rogers, Heather Murphy and Charlie Savage
item.category: National Commission on Terrorist Attacks upon the United States
item.media:description: As he ran for president in 2020, the Democratic candidate Joseph R. Biden Jr. laid a wreath at the Flight 93 National Memorial in Shanksville, Pa., and promised to review the documents related to the attacks for possible declassification and release.

item.title: Washington State Sets Vaccine Mandate for State and Health Care Workers
item.description: Employees who refuse to get vaccinated would face losing their jobs, Gov. Jay Inslee said.
item.dc:creator: Adeel Hassan
item.media:description: The Washington State police in Seattle last month. Gov. Jay Inslee announced on Monday that state workers must be vaccinated against the coronavirus as a condition of employment.

item.title: Biden Ramps Up Pressure on Cuba, Abandoning Obama’s Approach
item.description: Many Cubans thought the Biden administration would move to normalize relations with Havana. But the president has been tougher than Donald Trump on the island’s government.
item.dc:creator: Ernesto Londoño and Frances Robles
item.media:description: President Biden meeting with Cuban American leaders at the White House last month.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: A major climate report presents bleak findings.
item.dc:creator: Melina Delkic
item.media:description: The Dixie Fire, which destroyed one town and forced thousands to flee their homes in Northern California, became the second largest wildfire in state history on Sunday.

item.title: Suspect in Fire at French Cathedral Is Arrested in Killing of a Priest
item.description: The arrest of the suspect, a Rwandan asylum-seeker facing deportation, fueled criticism of the government’s immigration laws by right-wing politicians.
item.dc:creator: Norimitsu Onishi
item.media:description: A police officer standing outside the residence of the religious order in western France, where a priest was murdered.

item.title: 5 Takeaways From the U.N. Climate Report
item.description: The IPCC concluded that the world cannot avoid some devastating impacts of climate change, but that there is still a narrow window to keep the devastation from getting even worse.
item.dc:creator: Henry Fountain
item.media:description: The burning of fossil fuels is behind rising levels of greenhouse gases in the atmosphere.

item.title: The insurgents’ success in northern Afghanistan is an ill omen for Kabul.
item.description: In 1996, the Taliban captured Kabul before turning to the north. This time, they have already swept across a region that once defied them.
item.dc:creator: Sharif Hassan
item.media:credit: Jim Huylebroek for The New York Times
item.media:description: Militiamen loyal to Marshal Abdul Rashid Dostum on the front line against the Taliban northwest of Mazar-i-Sharif on July 10.

item.title: Deadly Clashes Threaten South Sudan’s Shaky Peace Deal
item.description: Infighting within the vice president’s party is undermining an already unstable ruling alliance that was formed after a five-year civil war killed 400,000 people.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.media:description: The shaky ruling alliance of President Salva Kiir of South Sudan, center, and Vice President Riek Machar, right, must respond to multiple humanitarian crises, flooding and the coronavirus pandemic.

item.title: Taliban Take a Sixth Afghan Provincial Capital City
item.description: Reeling on the battlefield, Afghan government officials face the difficult question of whether to let captured cities go in order to hold what they still have.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Najim Rahim and Sharif Hassan
item.media:description: A still from a video obtained from Taliban social media showing Taliban militants at the entrance gate of Aybak, Samangan province, in Afghanistan today.

item.title: Greece works to contain wildfires, as help arrives from other nations.
item.description: Wildfires were still burning in Turkey and other parts of Europe, where a protracted heat wave has created tinderbox conditions.
item.dc:creator: Niki Kitsantonis
item.media:description: A local resident reacts as he observes a large blaze during an attempt to extinguish forest fires approaching the village of Pefki on Evia, Greece's second largest island, on August 8, 2021.

item.title: Abbott is criticized for his ban on mask mandates as cases soar in Texas.
item.dc:creator: David Montgomery, Giulia Heyward and Edgar Sandoval
item.media:description: Gov. Greg Abbott of Texas during a visit to the border wall near the city of Pharr in June.

item.title: A Hotter Future
item.description: Human activity has significantly heated the Earth already. But several climate futures are still possible.
item.dc:creator: Somini Sengupta
item.media:description: A burning house in Pefki, Greece. Forest fires have raged for nearly two weeks as the region suffers a heat wave.

item.title: Settling Scores at a Fist-Fighting Festival in the Peruvian Andes
item.description: Each year on Dec. 25, thousands of locals gather in the town of Santo Tomás — dressed in elaborate costumes — to dance, drink and duke it out.
item.dc:creator: Mike Kai Chen
item.media:description: While the fights themselves can be brutal, each match begins and ends with a hug.

item.title: ‘There Is a Right and Wrong Way to Tickle a Rat’
item.description: Researchers in Australia tickled the rodents every day for a month to see if it would improve their emotional well-being.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:description: Researchers in Australia found that tickled lab rats generally responded better to human handling.

item.title: A Hotter Future Is Certain, According to U.N. Climate Report
item.description: Some devastating impacts of global warming are now unavoidable, a major new scientific report finds. But there is still a short window to stop things from getting even worse.
item.dc:creator: Brad Plumer and Henry Fountain
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:description: The Dixie Fire, which destroyed one town and forced thousands to flee their homes in Northern California, became the second largest wildfire in state history on Sunday.

item.title: Tokyo’s Olympic Bubble? Wait Till You See Beijing’s.
item.description: For the Winter Games, just six months away, China plans far more elaborate Covid-19 precautions than were taken at the Summer Olympics.
item.dc:creator: Keith Bradsher and Tariq Panja
item.media:description: Medical workers watched a figure skater during an April test run for a Winter Olympics venue in Beijing.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing
item.description: The Taliban take three more cities.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Afghans inspected damaged shops after fighting between Taliban and Afghan security forces in Kunduz city, northern Afghanistan, on Sunday.

item.title: 'Havana Syndrome' Attacks Still a Mystery
item.description: While the leading theory in the “Havana syndrome” cases is directed microwave attacks, a classified session for senior government officials said months of investigation were inconclusive.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.category: Office of the Director of National Intelligence
item.media:description: Vienna has become the latest center of reports of symptoms.

item.title: As Afghan Cities Fall to Taliban, Brutal New Chapter Unfolds
item.description: “This is now a different kind of war, reminiscent of Syria.” The seizure of five capitals has amplified fears about Afghanistan’s future after the U.S. withdrawal.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum, Najim Rahim, Sharif Hassan and Thomas Gibbons-Neff
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: The Taliban flag flying in the main square in Kunduz on Sunday.

item.title: Rising Covid Cases Force Organizers to Cancel New Orleans Jazz Fest
item.description: The festival had been moved to the fall in the hope that vaccinations would make the event possible.
item.dc:creator: Traci Carl
item.media:description: Revelers on Bourbon Street in New Orleans in July. The Delta variant of the coronavirus has led to a swift rise in infections in the area.

item.title: Jacob Desvarieux, Guitarist Who Forged Zouk Style, Dies at 65
item.description: His band, Kassav’, found millions of listeners as it held on to Caribbean roots while reaching out to the world. He died of Covid-19.
item.dc:creator: Jon Pareles
item.media:description: Jacob Desvarieux in 2009. A member of the band Kassav’, he created the Zouk style of music, which combined the Afro-Caribbean traditions of the French Antilles with sleek electronic dance music.

item.title: The Propaganda War Intensifies in Afghanistan as the Taliban Gain Ground
item.description: The effort to fend off panic and minimize losses has taken on outsize importance following the seizure of five provincial capitals by the Taliban.
item.dc:creator: Adam Nossiter and Fahim Abed
item.media:description: The Taliban flag, right, flying over the Pakistani-Afghan border crossing in Chaman, just across from Spin Boldak, on July 14.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing
item.description: The Taliban take three more cities.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: Shops damaged in fighting between Afghan security forces and the Taliban in Kunduz on Sunday.

item.title: The fall of Sar-i-Pul threatens a commercial hub in Afghanistan’s north.
item.description: The Taliban went all-out in recent days to seize Sar-i-Pul, putting even more pressure on Mazar-i-Sharif to its east.
item.dc:creator: Najim Rahim and Thomas Gibbons-Neff
